query: 给出参考文献时，请忠实给出原文档名，不要翻译成中文，也不要把relation等误当作文档名。当前非洲在病原体基因组监测、实验室网络建设和数字卫生系统应用方面的发展现状如何？中国可在哪些技术与基础设施领域提供有针对性的合作支持，以增强非洲的早期预警、快速响应和数据共享能力，特别是在猴痘和抗微生物药物耐药性（AMR）监测方面？

entities.description: Various regional, continental, and global organizations working in partnership to support pathogen genomics and public health responses in Africa.
Laboratory Systems and Networks refers to the coordinated frameworks of labs and networks across Africa aimed at enhancing diagnostics and pathogen surveillance.
Member states supported by Africa CDC in efforts to improve health systems and combat antimicrobial resistance across Africa.
Monitoring and analysis of disease-causing agents to detect emerging infections early, guide vaccine development and public health responses, strengthened under the Africa CDC and CEPI partnership.
Genomic testing capacity expanded from 7 to 40 laboratories across Africa as a direct result of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, enhancing disease surveillance and outbreak response.
Microbiology labs in 14 Africa CDC member states, with only 1.3% capable of testing key AMR pathogens, indicating low diagnostic capacity for antimicrobial resistance surveillance.

Africa CDC (Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention) is the specialized, continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union dedicated to strengthening health institutions and capacities across Africa. Its primary mission is to enhance disease surveillance, outbreak response, and emergency preparedness to detect, prevent, control, and manage health threats throughout the continent. As a leading public health institution in Africa, Africa CDC plays a central role in building health security and coordinating regional responses to infectious disease epidemics, including mpox, by collaborating closely with African governments and global partners such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the European Union, and Gavi.

Africa CDC actively co-leads initiatives like the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to address disease outbreaks and public health emergencies, while providing technical support, capacity building, and epidemic response coordination. The agency emphasizes genomic surveillance strategies as part of its comprehensive approach to managing public health challenges and strengthening health systems continent-wide.

In addition to its role in disease control, Africa CDC leads and supports critical vaccine manufacturing initiatives, including the African Vaccine Manufacturing Alliance (AVMA), with the goal of increasing local production to meet 60% of Africa’s demand for vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics by 2040. The agency promotes sustainable vaccine development, regulatory harmonization, decentralization of diagnostics, and localization of health product manufacturing to build resilient and self-sufficient health systems.

Operating under the African Union's Agenda 2063 and guided by a strategic plan for 2023-2027, Africa CDC strives to enhance health sovereignty, improve health outcomes, strengthen emergency response capabilities, and foster knowledge-sharing and institutional strengthening across African countries. Through these efforts, Africa CDC empowers Africa’s health security and advances the continent’s ability to manage current and future public health threats effectively.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency and specialized technical institution of the African Union. It is dedicated to supporting Member States across Africa in strengthening health systems by improving disease surveillance, emergency response, prevention, and control of diseases. Africa CDC focuses on enhancing the continent's capacity to detect, prevent, and respond to health emergencies, including combating deadly diseases such as drug-resistant infections and pandemics. Additionally, the agency plays a key role in communication and information dissemination related to health emergencies and outbreak response. Africa CDC also leads the African Union's public health initiatives, including pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, aiming to build resilient health systems throughout Africa.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention is a continental public health agency collaborating closely with WHO and the regional emergency hubs to strengthen emergency preparedness and health systems in Africa.
Private sector entities collaborating with Africa CDC and partners in public health initiatives including diagnostics and pathogen genomics.
National and regional governments across African countries engaged in collaborations to support the implementation of pathogen genomic surveillance and outbreak response.
A collaborative group under Africa CDC, working alongside ASLM, APHF, and Member States to coordinate laboratory and surveillance system strengthening projects across Africa.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is a continental public health agency mandated to address significant health threats in Africa, including coordinating epidemic responses by mobilizing African leaders, governments, and agencies. It declared mpox a Public Health Emergency of Continental Security (PHECS) on August 13, 2024.<SEP>Continental public health agency leading efforts to scale up local vaccine manufacturing in Africa. It hosted a High-Level meeting during the 77th World Health Assembly, led vaccine landscape analysis in partnership with Clinton Health Access Initiative and PATH, and directs initiatives like the African Pooled Procurement Mechanism for improving access and manufacturing.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union. It supports member states in strengthening health systems, improving disease surveillance, emergency response, and disease prevention and control across Africa. Africa CDC leads efforts to enhance epidemic and pandemic preparedness and is responsible for strengthening public health institutions and partnerships throughout the continent. The agency focuses on detecting and responding quickly and effectively to disease threats and outbreaks by implementing data-driven interventions and programs.

Africa is a continent facing a high burden of infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance, with mortality rates from antimicrobial resistance surpassing those from HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. It experiences numerous humanitarian crises and disease outbreaks annually, making it the primary geographical focus of various public health initiatives such as the JEAP initiative. Africa is also served by WHO AFRO and is central to efforts aimed at enhancing public health emergency preparedness and response, particularly in the context of diverse emergencies that are exacerbated by factors like climate change and conflict. Overall, Africa remains the critical region for partnership efforts focused on improving public health emergency preparedness and addressing ongoing health challenges.<SEP>Africa is the continent targeted by the AVMA and related initiatives aiming to increase local vaccine production, improve health security, and strengthen health systems and manufacturing capacity across regions including Central, Eastern, Northern, Southern, and Western Africa."|>"The African Vaccine Manufacturing Accelerator is a Boon for the Continent... Region: Central Africa, Eastern Africa, Northern Africa, Southern Africa, Western Africa

This group consists of international partners such as WHO, Africa CDC, UNICEF, US CDC, USAID, CEPI, Wellcome Trust, and GAVI, providing both technical expertise and financial support for mpox epidemic response and preparedness in African countries.

entities.entity: Africa Launches Continental Strategy to Decentralize Diagnostics and Accelerate Outbreak Response
entities.description: An Africa CDC-led continental initiative aimed at improving decentralized diagnostic capabilities and speeding up outbreak response mechanisms across Africa.<SEP>This is a continental strategy launch event focused on decentralizing diagnostics and improving response to outbreaks in Africa.<SEP>This is a continental-level initiative aimed at decentralizing diagnostic services and speeding up responses to disease outbreaks across Africa.

APHF is an organization established to mobilize resources and investments for critical African public health activities in support of Africa CDC and the African Union’s New Public Health Order, focusing on resource mobilisation, grants management, advocacy, private sector engagement, and public health data analysis.<SEP>APHF is an organization partnering with Africa CDC to mobilize resources and support public health laboratory systems and initiatives in Africa, specifically to advance pathogen genomics and pandemic preparedness.

entities.entity: Integrated Genomic Surveillance for Outbreak Detection (DETECT)
entities.description: DETECT is a new initiative by Africa CDC designed to improve genomic surveillance specifically focused on outbreak detection and response in Africa.
Organizations and entities that function as partners in implementing genomic surveillance projects and outbreak response activities across Africa.

Africa PGI 2.0 is an advanced framework and initiative aimed at developing resilient and integrated molecular diagnostic and genomic surveillance systems in Africa to strengthen detection and response to epidemic and pandemic-prone diseases.
A grouping of informational items including press releases, briefs, and advisories related to health emergency response and preparedness in Africa.

entities.entity: Integrated Genomic Surveillance and Data Sharing Platform (IGS)
entities.description: IGS is a newly launched project by Africa CDC aiming to enhance molecular detection, antimicrobial resistance genomic surveillance, and timely data sharing across Africa to strengthen outbreak detection.
Part of the initiative that drives adoption of innovative practices and digital technologies to improve access to medicines and health products in Africa.

Medical technologies, including vaccines and biologics, developed, manufactured, and deployed to prevent or respond to outbreaks, epitomizing Africa CDC and CEPI’s focus for epidemic and pandemic readiness.
The Africa Pathogen Genomics Initiative is a continental effort related to pathogen genomic research and surveillance across Africa.

entities.entity: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is the continental public health agency of the African Union mandated to support African member states in building robust health systems, safeguarding health security, and accelerating universal health coverage. It focuses on outbreak and pandemic prevention, health systems strengthening, and local manufacturing of health commodities including vaccines.

entities.entity: PATH (Program for Appropriate Technology in Health)
entities.description: Global health organization collaborating with Africa CDC and Clinton Health Access Initiative on vaccine supplier landscape analysis for Africa to inform manufacturing development.

entities.entity: Continental Strategy to Decentralize Diagnostics and Accelerate Outbreak Response
entities.description: This is a strategic initiative launched by Africa CDC aimed at decentralizing diagnostics and enhancing outbreak response capabilities across Africa.

Eastern Africa is a geographic sub-region within the continent of Africa that plays a critical and multifaceted role in health surveillance, disease intelligence, and emergency response efforts. It is a focal area for public health initiatives, including preparedness and response activities for outbreaks such as mpox. The region is highly affected by visceral leishmaniasis (VL), accounting for 73% of global VL cases in 2022, making it the primary target of the newly launched VL elimination framework. Eastern Africa is also a key operational zone for humanitarian and development programs, notably the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, underscoring its importance in addressing crises and enhancing resilience.

In addition, Eastern Africa actively participates in advanced scientific efforts like pathogen genomic activities that support the monitoring and understanding of infectious diseases. The region benefits significantly from coordinated health emergency initiatives and medical response strategies, including its involvement in AU-EU health partnerships aimed at pandemic preparedness and health system strengthening. Overall, Eastern Africa is a vital region for emergency management, public health strategy, humanitarian initiatives, and genomic research, making it central to both regional and global health security efforts.

entities.entity: Africa CDCs Platform for Harmonized Health Manufacturing in Africa (PHAHM)
entities.description: PHAHM is an Africa CDC-backed framework endorsed by African Heads of State to promote local health manufacturing capacity, including vaccines and related health commodities.

entities.entity: Africa Centre for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: A continent-wide public health institute focused on disease control and prevention in Africa, led by Dr Jean Kaseya, and engaged in advocating for strategic health investments.

Regional Emergency Hubs comprise three WHO-established centers in Africa (Dakar, Nairobi, Pretoria) created to improve rapid and effective responses to health emergencies, each with specialized functions including supply chain, medical personnel development, research, and genomic surveillance.

entities.entity: Local Manufacturing of Vaccines, Diagnostics, and Therapeutics
entities.description: A strategic focus area for Africa CDC and APHF to expand local production capacities for vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics across Africa to improve health system resilience.

A thematic focus area emphasizing strengthening surveillance, genomic sequencing, supply stockpiling, and rapid deployment of responders to improve Africa’s ability to manage public health emergencies.<SEP>Emergency Response and Preparedness is a broad and strategic theme encompassing activities, strategies, and measures aimed at responding to and preparing for public health emergencies, particularly health crises and outbreaks such as Mpox in Africa. It involves the rapid and effective mobilization of resources and capacities for Mpox surveillance, containment, and mitigation across the continent. This focus area prioritizes building capacity for timely and efficient response mechanisms, as highlighted in the Joint Action Plan and efforts led by Africa CDC. Overall, Emergency Response and Preparedness addresses the comprehensive and coordinated actions required to manage public health emergencies effectively throughout Africa.

Southern Africa is a geographic region in Africa that plays a significant role in regional health and emergency response initiatives, particularly concerning infectious disease outbreaks such as Mpox. It is actively involved in coordinated epidemic response and surveillance efforts, serving as a key area for disease intelligence and outbreak management. The region is part of various health emergency actions and preparedness efforts, including its inclusion in the implementation of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative. Additionally, Southern Africa is recognized as an important region for pathogen genomic activities, contributing to broader health strategies and outbreak response initiatives across the continent.<SEP>Southern Africa is a geographic region targeted in medical and health emergency initiatives by Africa CDC.<SEP>Southern Africa is included as a geographic focus for AU-EU health initiatives aiming to improve pandemic preparedness and advance health security."|>"Region: Southern Africa

Northern Africa is a geographic region in Africa recognized as a distinct regional zone within various frameworks and initiatives. It plays a significant role in disaster and crisis management, as it is listed within the emergency response and preparedness framework. The region is a key focus area for public health strengthening under the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative and is actively involved in broader public health and continental strategy activities. Northern Africa is particularly important for pathogen genomic activities, which highlights its role in health surveillance and epidemiological research. Additionally, the region is concerned with Mpox preparedness efforts and is affected by mpox, participating in continent-wide coordination for preparedness and response actions. Northern Africa is also relevant to health surveillance and antimicrobial resistance monitoring efforts, underscoring its comprehensive involvement in various public health initiatives and regional health security measures.<SEP>Northern Africa is a region within Africa involved in health response activities coordinated by Africa CDC.<SEP>Northern Africa is among target areas for African Union-European Union health programs addressing pandemic prevention, vaccine production, and health systems resilience."|>"Region: Northern Africa

entities.entity: WHO African Regions Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response Strategy
entities.description: A WHO African regional strategy covering integrated disease surveillance and response for the period 2020-2030 to improve epidemic detection and health emergency management including for mpox.

Central Africa is a geographic region of the African continent encompassing multiple countries that are actively involved in Mpox surveillance and research. It is recognized as one of the African regions affected by Mpox outbreaks and plays a significant role in regional surveillance and coordinated response efforts. Central Africa is a focal area for various health initiatives and interventions led by the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), particularly aimed at strengthening diagnostics, surveillance, regulation, and emergency response systems. Within this region, France supports several regional health projects aligned with Africa CDC’s objectives. Additionally, Central Africa is a key area of focus for pathogen genomic activities and broader health and surveillance initiatives. It is also one of the regional zones targeted by the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative as well as health initiatives and partnerships stemming from the Africa Union-European Union (AU-EU) collaboration, all aimed at strengthening regional public health and response systems. Overall, Central Africa is an important region for strategic initiatives and preparedness activities designed to improve health outcomes across the African continent.

entities.entity: Malawi Launches Second Edition of Pathogen Genomic Surveillance Strategy and Implementation Plan
entities.description: A public health initiative in Malawi to enhance pathogen genomic surveillance for better outbreak detection and response, mentioned as part of Africa CDC related activities.<SEP>Malawi Launches Second Edition of Pathogen Genomic Surveillance Strategy and Implementation Plan is a country-level event marking the launch of an updated genomic surveillance strategy aimed at enhancing pathogen tracking, outbreak detection, and improving disease monitoring and health responses to infectious diseases. This initiative represents Malawi's continued effort to strengthen its capacity for pathogen genomic surveillance through the release of the second edition of its comprehensive strategy and implementation plan.

entities.entity: Africa CDC Institute for Pathogen Genomics
entities.description: Africa CDC Institute for Pathogen Genomics is an institute focused on pathogen genomics within the Africa CDC framework, contributing to genomic surveillance and outbreak response.
Efforts aimed at fostering supporting environments including networks and infrastructure to sustain pharmaceutical manufacturing and innovation in Africa.

The United Kingdom is a sovereign country in Europe making significant financial commitments towards global health, focusing on research, development, and tackling health challenges worldwide, particularly in Africa.
Dr Salih emphasized the multifaceted threat of AMR beyond health, including impacts on food safety, security, livelihoods, and economies.

entities.entity: European Commission Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Authority (HERA)
entities.description: HERA is a directorate-general of the European Commission focused on preventing, detecting, and rapidly responding to health emergencies, and it collaborates with Africa CDC on strengthening outbreak detection and genomic surveillance in Africa.
The African Union is a continental union consisting of 55 member states in Africa engaged as partners in health initiatives including Africa CDC’s genomic surveillance projects.

entities.entity: Malawi Second Edition of Pathogen Genomic Surveillance Strategy and Implementation Plan
entities.description: This event marks the launch in Malawi of the second edition of a strategy and implementation plan focusing on pathogen genomic surveillance to better track and respond to infectious disease outbreaks.

The United Kingdom government has committed significant financial resources and partnerships aimed at advancing global health, supporting disease control and vaccine development initiatives, particularly in Africa and low- and middle-income countries.

Cameroon is an African country located in Central Africa that has recently taken significant steps in public health and disease control. Beginning on 22 January 2024, Cameroon started integrating the RTS,S malaria vaccine into its national routine immunization program, covering over 500 health facilities across 42 health districts in 10 regions. The country is actively involved within the scope of Africa CDC health-related strategies and outbreak responses, highlighting its engagement in continental health initiatives. Additionally, Cameroon is one of five African Union Member States initially targeted to receive cold chain equipment aimed at improving vaccine-storage infrastructure and immunization services. Furthermore, Cameroon has been included in the initial focus of Mpox research conducted by the Consortium, underscoring its role in emerging infectious disease studies in Africa.

The African Medicines Agency (AMA) is a continent-wide regulatory body requiring the collective support of African member states to provide affordable, quality medicines and strengthen regulatory harmonization.<SEP>The African Medicines Agency is a continental regulatory body aimed at harmonizing and enhancing medicine regulation across Africa to improve access to safe and effective health products.

AMR refers to the growing resistance of microbes to antimicrobial drugs, representing a critical health challenge addressed in AU-EU health collaborations."|>"...strengthening pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health, AMR, digital health, climate and health.<SEP>Antimicrobial Resistance refers to the ability of microorganisms to withstand antimicrobial treatments, posing significant public health challenges which are a focal theme in regional surveillance and disease intelligence efforts in Africa.<SEP>Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is the process by which microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites develop resistance to antimicrobial drugs, leading to higher mortality, treatment failures, and disease spread; it is a critical health threat in Africa linked to misuse of drugs in healthcare, agriculture, and food systems.

The African Society for Laboratory Medicine is an organization working to improve laboratory capabilities in Africa, particularly for antimicrobial resistance testing, aiming to promote data-driven solutions for public health.

entities.entity: United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting
entities.description: The United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting is an upcoming international forum scheduled for September, expected to address global action plans on antimicrobial resistance, informed by reports such as the Africa CDC's on AMR in Africa.

The European Union (EU) is a political and economic union of member states in Europe, leading the European delegation in strategic health partnerships with Africa to strengthen global and African health.<SEP>The European Union is a political and economic union of member states in Europe that co-funded Africa CDC’s genomic surveillance and molecular diagnostics projects.<SEP>The European Union is a supranational organization committed to global health improvement through partnerships with African counterparts, focusing on pandemic agreements, health system strengthening, funding programs, and health security initiatives under the AU-EU Health partnership framework.

Capacity Building involves training, learning exchanges, benchmarking visits, and simulation exercises designed to enhance the skills and preparedness of human resources and national laboratories in mpox response.

relations.description: Africa CDC and WHO collaborate closely to strengthen health emergency preparedness and response in Africa. They provide technical support through mechanisms established at multiple levels, including headquarters, regional centres, and country offices, specifically for the mpox response. Together, they have launched the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP), a strategic partnership aimed at enhancing health systems and combating disease outbreaks across the continent. This initiative reflects their joint commitment to improving Africa's capacity to manage health emergencies effectively.

Antimicrobial Resistance is a Greater Threat than HIV-AIDS, TB and Malaria, Says New Report – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Antimicrobial Resistance is a Greater Threat than HIV-AIDS, TB and Malaria, Says New Report
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, August 15
– The likelihood of falling ill or dying from diseases that resist treatment has escalated in Africa, with children and other vulnerable groups being most at risk, according to a new report by the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC).
“The continent faces the highest mortality rate from antimicrobial resistance (AMR), with 27.3 deaths per 100,000—exceeding the combined death toll from HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria,” said the ‘African Union Landmark Report’ launched today at Africa CDC headquarters.
Africa bears a significant burden of infectious diseases, accounting for approximately 95% of malaria deaths, 70% of people living with HIV, and 25% of TB deaths globally, said the report.
“We must not ignore this silent threat that disproportionately impacts the most vulnerable among us,” said Africa CDC Deputy Director General, Dr Raji Tajudeen.
AMR occurs when microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites develop resistance to antimicrobial drugs, a process hastened by human behaviors such as the misuse and overuse of these drugs in healthcare, agriculture and food systems. This renders antibiotics and other antimicrobials less effective, causing treatment failures, increased disease spread, severe illness, disability and higher mortality rates.
Despite the estimated USD2-6 billion needed annually for an effective AMR response across Africa, current funding is only a tenth of that allocated to other major diseases. This underfunding makes AMR a significant barrier to sustainable development, hindering progress toward the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the African Union’s Agenda 2063.
An estimated 700,000 people die annually from drug-resistant infections globally. Without timely intervention, this number is projected to reach 10 million by 2050, with Africa accounting for 4.5 million.
“Fighting disease requires resources and working with member states and our partners we need to do all we can to save lives,” said Dr Tajudeen, speaking at the launch of a report on AMR in Africa. The event also initiated discussions on a roadmap and targets to advance Africa’s battle against AMR. The outcomes are expected to inform the upcoming United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting in September—a crucial platform for global action on this escalating crisis.
Dr Huyam Salih, the director of the African Union-Inter African Bureau for Animal Resources (AU-IBAR), emphasized the critical role that the AU must play in combating AMR. “Antimicrobial resistance is not just a health issue—it is a threat to our agrifood systems, food safety, food security, livelihoods, and economies,” she said.
By 2050, global healthcare costs could exceed USD1 trillion per year, and livestock production could decline by 2.6% to 7.5% annually due to AMR, according to Dr Salih. “In Africa, the situation is particularly alarming, with 37 countries reporting the prevalence of AMR in animal farms, yet only 16% of African countries are conducting routine AMR surveillance in animals as of 2023,” she said.
Dr Salih also called for urgent action to strengthen leadership, expand surveillance and data systems, promote the responsible use of antimicrobials, improve public and animal health systems, and secure sustainable financing to combat AMR effectively. “Our health, our food, and our future depend on the actions we take now,” she stressed.
Dr Tajudeen said addressing AMR in Africa requires engaging all levels of society in a comprehensive and multi-sectoral approach. “Unless we work together, overcoming antimicrobial resistance will be a difficult and long-drawn process that will cost lives,” he said.
Currently, millions in Africa lack access to essential antibiotics, with a study by Africa CDC and the African Society for Laboratory Medicine revealing that only 1.3% of microbiology labs in 14 member states can test for key AMR pathogens.
The head of the African Society for Laboratory Medicine, Mr. Nqobile Ndlovu, reaffirmed the organization’s commitment to strengthening African laboratory capacities to combat antimicrobial resistance. “Our goal is to ensure the continued efficacy of treatments and promote data-driven solutions to safeguard public health across the continent,” he said.
Dr Tajudeen underscored the importance of prioritizing infection prevention, strengthening health and food systems, developing human resources, ensuring sustainable access to diagnostics and therapeutics, and investing in laboratory infrastructure for effective surveillance and data generation.
The report recommends an increase in the availability of high-quality diagnostics, vaccines, and antimicrobials for high-priority pathogens in high-risk African countries.

Africa CDC and CEPI deepen partnership to fortify African preparedness against disease outbreaks – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and CEPI deepen partnership to fortify African preparedness against disease outbreaks
May 28, 2024; Geneva, Switzerland:
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on the sidelines of the 77th World Health Assembly to expand their partnership to strengthen epidemic and pandemic prevention, preparedness and response in Africa.
United by a shared mission, the organizations will collaborate to boost regional vaccine research, development, and sustainable manufacturing leadership and capabilities in Africa, fostering a faster and more equitable response to emerging infectious diseases.
“The New Public Health Order calls to action to build resilient health systems capable of managing recurrent, high-impact infectious disease and outbreaks; an action-oriented partnership such as this is at the core,” said
Dr. Jean Kaseya, Africa CDC’s Director General
. “This collaboration with CEPI in research, clinical trials, and local manufacturing of medical countermeasures will elevate Africa’s readiness against outbreaks, epidemics, and pandemics, thus consolidating the continent’s preparedness far beyond where we were prior to the COVID-19 pandemic.”
“African leadership and capabilities will be key for ensuring the continent can respond to increasingly frequent infectious disease outbreaks,” said
Richard Hatchett, CEPI’s Chief Executive Officer.
“The preparatory work to manage these outbreaks—from greater vaccine manufacturing capacity to clinical trial readiness—must be undertaken now. CEPI stands ready to support Africa CDC in the realisation of these goals and to further strengthen Africa’s preparedness and resilience against future outbreaks.”
In line with the African Union’s (A.U.) ambition to produce 60% of the continent’s vaccine needs in Africa by 2040 under the Africa CDC’s Partnerships for African Vaccine Manufacturing (PAVM);  the expanded partnership will ultimately focus its efforts on enhancing research and development, building a workforce as well as supply chain optimization to support resilient health systems This ambition will increase vaccine sovereignty and reduce external reliance, helping prevent a recurrence of the vaccine inequity seen during the COVID-19 response in Africa.
To boost vaccine accessibility and efficiency and meet this goal, there is a need to invest in vaccine R&D and manufacturing innovations, amongst others, and build a resilient regional supply chain. To that end, Africa CDC and CEPI will coordinate to fund innovations accelerating speed, scale, or accessibility for initial implementation with African manufacturers. This investment will support sustainable manufacturing for routine vaccinations in Africa, and—in the event of an outbreak—these facilities can be mobilized to produce response vaccines promptly.
In alignment with Africa CDC, the partnership also aims to bolster Africa’s research ecosystem and clinical trial infrastructure, including targeted capacity strengthening through CEPI’s
Research Preparedness Program
—which, directed by regional experts, aims to build capacity for conducting high-quality Phase 3 efficacy trials.
Building on existing clinical trial capability in some African countries is vital as vaccine candidates against endemic diseases, such as
Lassa fever
, progress into late-stage development. Phase 3 trials provide essential data required for vaccine approval and must take place in regions where the disease is prevalent. A
CEPI-funded Phase 2 trial for a Lassa fever vaccine
candidate is already underway; it is crucial that if this candidate, or another, is successful, there is regional capability to further its path toward licensure. Once established, this capability can benefit other regional actors advancing to late-stage research.
The organizations will also collaborate to enhance vaccine safety protocols, biosecurity, pathogen surveillance, investment in capacity building, and other areas that help ensure overall African readiness for emergency vaccine responses.
Africa CDC and CEPI are committed to this cooperation, which will strengthen collaboration and deliver tangible results to deliver Africa’s long-term health security ambitions.
—END
—
Notes to Editors
About CEPI
CEPI was launched in 2017 as an innovative partnership between public, private, philanthropic and civil organisations. Its mission is to accelerate the development of vaccines and other biologic countermeasures against epidemic and pandemic disease threats and enable equitable access to them. CEPI has supported the development of more than 50 vaccine candidates or platform technologies against multiple known high-risk pathogens and is also advancing the development of rapid response platforms for vaccines against a future Disease X. Central to CEPI’s pandemic-beating five-year plan for 2022-2026 is the ‘100 Days Mission’ to compress the time taken to develop safe, effective, globally accessible vaccines against new threats to just 100 days.
About Africa CDC
About Africa CDC: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union that supports member states in their efforts to strengthen health systems and improve surveillance, emergency response, and prevention and control of diseases. Learn more at:
https://africacdc.org

Africa CDC and Mastercard Foundation launch phase 2 of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods (SLL) initiative to strengthen Africa’s public health systems – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and Mastercard Foundation launch phase 2 of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods (SLL) initiative to strengthen Africa’s public health systems
November 28, 2023,
Lusaka
– The Africa CDC and the Mastercard Foundation have entered a new phase of their partnership on the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative in the aftermath of WHO’s declaration of the end of COVID-19 pandemic as a public health emergency of international concern. The Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, a bold and unprecedented $1.5 billion partnership, was launched in June 2021. This innovative and ground-breaking partnership aimed to purchase COVID-19 vaccines, roll out vaccinations, build the vaccine manufacturing workforce for the continent, and strengthen the Africa CDC to ensure long-term health security for Africa.
Unprecedented in scale, speed and inclusion of African organisations, the partnership has
contributed to the continent’s current vaccination rate of 53 per cent of
the target population, up from just 3 per cent at the start of the initiative. The partnership has also trained, equipped, and deployed 38,000 health workers, creating a robust frontline in safeguarding public health locally. It has provided job opportunities for 23,000 individuals and integrated over 600 COVID-19 vaccination centres into healthcare systems. Additionally, this initiative led to the expansion of genomic testing capabilities from seven to 40 laboratories across the continent.
The review of Phase 1 of this initiative, among fifteen implementing partners across 29 countries, conducted by Deloitte, indicates that the vast majority of funds disbursed were used effectively and as intended. Likewise, ongoing monitoring by KPMG has confirmed that partners not only showed strength in programmatic results but also improved the institutional capacity for greater sustainability and institutional resilience.
“Our Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative with the Mastercard Foundation has shown the power of respectful and action-oriented partnerships rooted in collaboration, coordination and systems strengthening. The experience and learnings from Phase I will enable us to move with greater speed and scale to deliver with accelerated impact to our member states” said
Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director General of the Africa CDC
.
In its second phase, the partnership will expand its scope and scale, focusing on completing the vaccination of healthcare workers and vulnerable groups, building a robust workforce of community health workers, ensuring pandemic preparedness by bolstering national public health institutions, laboratory capacities, data access and quality, local manufacturing of vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics, and continuing strengthening of Africa CDC.
“While the global pandemic may be declared over, the need to continue investing in our health systems, build our workforce and prepare for future pandemics remains urgent. This partnership will ensure that we have strong health institutions and systems. We aim to enable thousands of young people to build their careers in healthcare and contribute to improving lives in Africa,” said
Reeta Roy, President, and CEO of the Mastercard Foundation.
The Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative stands out as a testament to the power of African-led health solutions. As it progresses to its next phase, partnerships will continue to play a crucial role in shaping a New Public Health Order for Africa. Africa CDC and the Mastercard Foundation remain committed to improving the health and well-being of all Africans.
-ENDS-
About the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
Africa CDC is a continental autonomous health agency of the African Union established to support public health initiatives of Member States and strengthen the capacity of their public health institutions to detect, prevent, control, and respond quickly and effectively to disease threats. For more information, please visit:
https://africacdc.org
About the Mastercard Foundation
The Mastercard Foundation is a registered Canadian charity and one of the largest foundations in the world. It works with visionary organisations to advance education and financial inclusion, enabling young people in Africa and Indigenous youth in Canada to access dignified and fulfilling work. Established in 2006 through the generosity of Mastercard when it became a public company, the Foundation is an independent organisation separate from the company, with offices in Toronto, Kigali, Accra, Nairobi, Kampala, Lagos, Dakar, and Addis Ababa. Its policies, operations, and program decisions are determined by the Foundation’s Board of Directors and leadership. For more information on the Foundation, please visit
www.mastercardfdn.org
.

,
H.E. Stella KYRIAKIDES
“
An ever-closer partnership between the African Union and the European Union is indispensable for public health. We want to work more closely with our African partners on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health and anti-microbial resistance, as well as the health effects of climate change. These are core objectives for our EU Global Health Strategy and the foundations of our cooperation with the African continent. We are now at a critical stage of the negotiations on the pandemic agreement and the international health regulations, with which we would provide new multilateral solutions to common challenges. The EU is committed to conclude the negotiations by May, a responsibility equally shared by all nations. I am pleased that the African Union and EU are joining voices and taking concrete steps to support global health internationally.
”
Africa CDC Director General,
H.E Dr Jean Kaseya
“As we navigate the complexities of global health, Africa is on the path towards self-sufficiency through equitable access to medical products. Africa’s target of producing 60% of vaccines by 2040 through the Africa CDC underscores our commitment to health sovereignty. Through strategic partnerships like the EU-AU collaboration, we accelerate our capabilities, leveraging expertise and resources to build resilient health systems and strengthen Pandemic preparedness.”
Specific outcomes of the high-level conference include the following concrete engagements:
Working Arrangement between Africa CDC and the European Commission to best implement the expanded strategic AU-EU Health partnership;
The European Commission and the Belgian Presidency announced additional TEI MAV+ funding for the advancement of the African Medicines Agency;
The announcement of procurement commitments by Global Health Initiatives to buy in Africa for Africa;
Three additional Team Europe Initiatives on health were launched: Health Security using a One Health approach, Digital Health, and Public Health Institutes;
The Team Europe Initiative (TEI) on Social Protection was launched;
Work product leads for Team Europe and Team Africa were confirmed;
A new programme ‘SafeBirth Africa’ to support improved access to innovative life-saving commodities for sexual and reproductive health in Africa. The programme will be implemented by Unitaid and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), supported by a financial contribution of €20 million from the EU budget under the Team Europe Initiative on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights that was launched in Kigali in December 2022;
An expanded AU-EU High Level Steering Meeting (HLSM) at DG-level will jointly oversee regional heath TEIs.
-END-

African researchers propose Mpox research group – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Stories
African researchers propose Mpox research group
African researchers have proposed setting up a multicountry research group to mitigate against recurring epidemics in Africa and prevent future pandemics. The planned Mpox Research Consortium (MpoxReC) was announced during the Mpox in Africa—High-Level Emergency Regional Meeting, held in the Democratic Republic of Congo from 11 to 13 April. “We propose the establishment of an African-led multi-disciplinary, multicountry Mpox Research Consortium (MpoxReC) in Africa with the overarching goal of establishing a research network to advance the elimination of mpox,” Jean B. Nachega (Professor Extraordinary of Medicine Department of Medicine, Division of Infectious Diseases Stellenbosch University Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences) told the meeting.
Mpox is endemic to 12 countries in Africa
Nachega said Africa has faced a long-standing unmet need for sustainable local diagnostic laboratories and research capacity for mpox.
“MpoxReC will address these needs and provide outcome monitoring and surveillance across endemic African countries while simultaneously contributing to much-needed South-South, multi-disciplinary, and inter-professional research collaborations and capacity-building,” he said. He said the continent needs to share national and regional epidemic preparedness frameworks on the disease.
The research group, which includes global partners and African collaborators, will initially focus on Cameroon, the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Nigeria, and the Republic of Congo.  Professor Nadia Sam-Agudu will lead researchers at the University of Cape Coast Ghana, Professor Samuel Nakoune Yandoko will head the team at Pasteur Institute in Bangui, the Central African Republic, co-principal investigators Professor Jean-Jacques Muyembe and Professor Placide Mbala will represent the DRC’s Institute National Research Biomedical, Professor Dimie Ogoina from Niger Delta University Teaching Hospital will represent Nigeria, Cameroon’s Pasteur Institute research team will be led by Professor Richard Njouom and Congo will be led by Professor Francine Ntoumi from the Congolese Foundation for Medical Research. Expansion to other African countries will take place later.

Partnership for Public Health Emergencies Preparedness & Response Seeks 1 Billion USD | Africa CDC and WHO Strengthen Efforts to Safeguard Africa's Health – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Stories
Partnership for Public Health Emergencies Preparedness & Response Seeks 1 Billion USD | Africa CDC and WHO Strengthen Efforts to Safeguard Africa’s Health
Africa’s two leading public health institutions are seeking 1 billion USD for their partnership to respond to public health emergencies triggered by climate change and conflict-related disasters, aiming to build health security on the continent.
Africa CDC and the World Health Organization (WHO) met on 27 May in Geneva, a year after launching the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) at the 76th World Health Assembly.
“The JEAP is looking forward to mobilizing close to 1 billion USD to address critical gaps and strengthen the systems on the continent to better prepare, detect, and respond to health emergencies by 2027,” said Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director General of the Africa CDC. “We think we can make it happen if we put our hands together,” he told the partners at the meeting.
For the first time, the JEAP partnership developed 17 multi-country and regional proposals for submission to the second round of the Pandemic Fund compared to fewer than three in the first round.
“We are aware that the pandemic envelope is limited in meeting all needs, and that is why we are inviting you to join the JEAP movement,” said Dr. Kaseya.
JEAP is a five-year strategic collaboration aimed at boosting emergency preparedness and response efforts throughout Africa, helping to ensure effective responses to disease outbreaks during humanitarian crises. On average, 100 disease outbreaks are reported annually in Africa.
“The collaboration between the Africa CDC and WHO exemplifies the power of partnership in global health,” said Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, WHO Regional Director for Africa. “JEAP will bolster our efforts to fight public health emergencies, saving lives and protecting our communities. We are proud to stand with Africa CDC and work towards a healthier and safer future for all Africans,” she said.
The plan builds upon existing frameworks and initiatives, including the Africa CDC’s New Public Health Order and WHO AFRO’s Regional Strategy for Health Security and Emergencies (2022-2030).
JEAP prioritizes strengthening surveillance intelligence and genomic sequencing for quicker detection, stockpiling emergency supplies at newly established sub-regional hubs to improve emergency response operations, and deploying first responders within 24-48 hours of a disease outbreak. They also plan to overcome supply chain barriers by reducing delays in delivering lifesaving supplies from 20 days to 24-48 hours, mitigating morbidity and mortality. The JEAP partnership welcomed UNICEF as the first partner to join this partnership, which holds great promise for transforming health security on the continent.

Africa CDC and WHO Launch Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to Strengthen Health Systems and Combat Disease Outbreaks in Africa - AHRO Global Health Research Center
Skip to content
Africa CDC and WHO Launch Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to Strengthen Health Systems and Combat Disease Outbreaks in Africa
AHRO Global Health Research Center
-
Africa CDC and WHO Launch Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to Strengthen Health Systems and Combat Disease Outbreaks in Africa
05 Jun
2023
By
Afhro
From humanitarian crises triggered by conflict to climate-change induced disasters, Africa deals with over 100 disease outbreaks every year. To tackle these challenges, the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and World Health Organization (WHO) are pleased to announce the launch of a Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP). This pioneering five-year strategic collaboration will boost emergency preparedness and response efforts throughout Africa and thus ensure disease outbreaks during humanitarian crises and otherwise are managed efficiently.
The JEAP underlines the shared vision of Africa’s two leading public health institutions – to strengthen emergency preparedness and response and health systems on the continent. The plan builds upon existing frameworks and initiatives while capitalising on the Africa CDC and WHO’s unique capabilities and resources. Aligned with the Africa CDC’s New Public Health Order, WHO AFRO’s Regional Strategy for Health Security and Emergencies (2022-2030), and WHO EMRO’s four-year strategy for the Eastern Mediterranean region to address health emergencies – the JEAP strengthens emergency preparedness and response across six critical areas.
“The collaboration between the Africa CDC and WHO exemplifies the power of partnership in global health. JEAP will bolster our collective efforts to fight public health emergencies, saving lives and protecting our communities. We are proud to stand with the Africa CDC and work towards a healthier and safer future for all Africans,” said Dr Matshidiso Moeti, WHO Regional Director for Africa.
Priority areas of action are strengthening surveillance intelligence and genomic sequencing for quicker detection; stockpiling emergency supplies at newly established sub-regional hubs to improve emergency response operations (70% of response activities during emergencies relate to such supply chain measures); and deploying first responders within 24-48 hours of a disease outbreak. Most critically, this ground-breaking collaboration outlines impactful initiatives to be implemented in unison with countries to enhance the continent’s capacity to detect, monitor, and respond swiftly to health emergencies. In a first-of-its kind collaboration, the JEAP serves as a guiding beacon for targeted emergency response interventions and embodies the importance of cross-cutting collaboration, knowledge sharing, and resource mobilisation.
“Africa CDC is proud to partner for this important continental strategic plan. Joining forces with WHO will significantly improve our ability to safeguard the health of African populations during times of crisis. Together, we will build resilient health systems and ensure a coordinated and effective response to emergencies across the continent,” said Dr Jean Kaseya, Director General of the Africa CDC.
In an inspiring take, Dr Ahmed Al-Mandhari, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean reiterated, “This visionary collaboration will breathe new life into the efficiency of current coordination mechanisms, strengthen institutions, and ultimately help us deliver quality healthcare services to our communities.”
These efforts are galvanising the commitments from governments, health agencies, and stakeholders to strengthen health emergency preparedness, detection, and response efforts. Through collective action and unwavering commitment, we will build resilient systems, enhance capacities, and safeguard the well-being of our communities. This partnership is a testament to our unwavering dedication to a healthier, safer Africa.
